ionic.title: Ionic Compounds
ionic.body:
Ionic compounds

Ionic compounds form from a metal cation and a nonmetal anion. The total positive and negative charge must balance to zero.

Name the cation first, then the anion. Main-group metals keep a fixed charge; transition metals use Roman numerals to show the cation charge.

  • NaCl: sodium chloride
  • FeCl2: iron(II) chloride

covalent.title: Molecular (Covalent) Compounds
covalent.body:
Molecular (covalent) compounds

Molecular compounds form when two nonmetals share electrons. Use prefixes (mono-, di-, tri-, tetra-, etc.) to show how many atoms of each element are present.

The first element keeps its name (usually omit mono-). The second element ends with -ide.

  • CO: carbon monoxide
  • CO2: carbon dioxide

acids.title: Acids
acids.body:
Acids

Aqueous means the acid is dissolved in water and labeled (aq). A binary acid is hydrogen plus a single nonmetal, with no oxygen.

Aqueous binary acids use hydro- + root + -ic acid. Oxyacids contain oxygen and are named from oxyanions: -ate becomes -ic, and -ite becomes -ous.

  • HCl(aq): hydrochloric acid
  • HNO3(aq): nitric acid

polyatomic.title: Polyatomic Ions
polyatomic.body:
Polyatomic ions

Polyatomic ions are groups of atoms that carry a net charge and act as a single unit in a compound.

Keep the polyatomic ion name. Use parentheses when more than one is needed.

Examples: sulfate (SO42-), nitrate (NO3-), ammonium (NH4+).

hydrates.title: Hydrates
hydrates.body:
Hydrates

Hydrates are salts that include water molecules in their crystal structure.

Name the salt + prefix-hydrate. The prefix shows how many water molecules are present.

  • CuSO4·5H2O: copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate

roman.title: Roman Numerals
roman.body:
Roman numerals

Some metals can form more than one charge. Use a Roman numeral to show the metal's charge.

  • FeO: iron(II) oxide
  • Fe2O3: iron(III) oxide

phases.title: Phases
phases.body:
Phases

Phase labels show physical state: (s) solid, (l) liquid, (g) gas, (aq) aqueous (dissolved in water).

The phase can change the name. Example: HCl(aq) is hydrochloric acid, while HCl(g) is hydrogen chloride.
